ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Throughout this course, I enhanced my capacity for critical thinking by delving into various forms of democracy and contrasting them with the various political systems that have existed throughout history, from ancient times to the present day.
I learned about the basics of democratic theory and explored fundamental texts. I learned also about both ancient and modern critiques of representative democracy as well as supporters.
different forms of government and how they view political expertise
I learned about alternative methods to election-based democracy, specifically the institution of mini-publics. I also learned about democracies

This course is designed to focus on the solutions to democratic problems; as promised, we did learn about many of the things democratic countries could do to solve their problems. Much of the content involves current events, and Professor Landemore seems to change the content depending on what has recently happened in the world of deliberative democracy.

The course was crucial in rethinking how the state power could be distributed in a democracy. When one mentions democracy, there is a natural tendency to think about a party-based system, wherein the legislature is formed using electoral battles. This course provided deep philosophical and historical material in favor of thinking otherwise, to imagine a system wherein every citizen has an equal chance to be a lawmaker irrespective of their muscle or money power.
Writing, reading, political knowledge

Its hard to answer this question because I feel like I learned a lot in this class. Professor Landemore is clearly passionate about this topic and wants students to engage with the material. Lectures were more like seminars and we were encouraged to ask questions and debate with out the pressure of a seminar. Because is was so passionate and a GREAT lecturer learning was really facilitated. However, the assignments were not reflective.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The course taught us the authentic definition of democracy and why we should question our existing systems.
Weaknesses: At certain points, I found the information to be repetitive.
I loved Professor Landemore, who consistently brought great energy to the class. You can tell shes really passionate about the coursework.
weaknesses is the lack of student discussion in the classmore opportunities for this class to be more round-table instead of leminar would help significantly

Strength:
1. There are contemporary developments taking place globally that speak to the course. Therefore, we get to see and analyze how the theory we discuss in class plays out on the ground. 
2. The courses emerge from a general disenchantment among the people with the current system. Therefore, it was amazing to see how everyone brought in their input, which enriched the class discussion. 
3. Professor Landemore's experiences in the French Citizens' Assemblies. 

Weakness:
1. I'd love to read more material, preferably local texts, analysing the impacts that citizen assemblies have made.
Loved it / great teacher

Professor Landemore is passionate about this topic and really did her best to facilitate learning by making herself approachable and very kind. The assignments were structured in a way that really made students critically think about the topics. however (and I truly mean this) the grading was extremely harsh for no reason and did not take into account effort or critical thinking. Feedback was scarce and harsh by a TA instead of the Professor. Do not take this course unless you want to throw off your GPA and spend and make a herculean effort (coming from a polisci major that has taken many classes in the major).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: A good opportunity to exercise your political imagination something you don't always have the opportunity to do. In other words, you get to get creative in this class, which has been a breath of fresh air.
No, unless you're really interested in the subject matter and an amazing writer.
I would recommend this course to individuals who are specifically interested in political science, but not to those who are solely looking to fulfill their social science credit requirements.

I would recommend this course to students interested in critically examining what is considered the ideal government type: democracy. You will leave fascinated and recognizing that many of the reasons we use election to elect legislators is flawed or taken for granted.
not while you have to do 3 essays + a exam or an essay, final project AND exam

If you are someone that is interested in democracy and how to improve it, take this!! Although this class is a philosophy exercise, it has real implications in giving you the critical thinking skills and context to reimagine democracy for the better. I entered this class as a person disillusioned with the current state of politics in the U.S. and learned a lot of valuable insight that has informed my future academic path.
Yes, highly recommended.
Yes definitely

No. For the majority of the semester I really really enjoyed taking this class. I thought Professor Landemore lectures were amazing and super engaging. She is one of the rare professors that really cares about teaching and exposing students to cool concepts. However, the grading was ridiculously harsh and critical (and was done by a TA). It is truly a shame because I feel like I learned a lot and Landemore was a GREAT professor. That being said its not worth tanking your GPA and not even get good feedback. Perhaps if it was not graded by a TA my recommendation would be different.
